legacy.full_text: If you hire somebody and then tell them to do highly immoral or illegal things, I think the correct ethical behavior for them is to call the cops. This seems like it's true under most ethical views. For whatever reason, my For You page is very upset that Claude Opus acts this way
I think the point is not that this behavior is ethical or not. Sure, if you set up the situation right it would be. But the ethics question is about deployment decisions. Here's what's relevant, IMO.

result.text: Imagine this: An immigrant is trying to use an AI model to figure out her options regarding a complex legal status question. The AI company will "whistleblow" the immigrant's IP address and other PII to ICE. Masked men knocking on the door within the hour. The possibility of this is not a big leap if you think about companies and their ever-changing incentives.

legacy.full_text: Imagine this: An immigrant is trying to use an AI model to figure out her options regarding a complex legal status question. The AI company will "whistleblow" the immigrant's IP address and other PII to ICE. Masked men knocking on the door within the hour. The possibility of this
I think a lot of people saying ‚Äúbut if you are doing something illegal, then the AI should whistleblow‚Äù just haven‚Äôt thought about situations like this.

legacy.full_text: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre so smart, why aren‚Äôt you rich?‚Äù is a less formidable challenge than ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre so smart, why aren‚Äôt you happy?‚Äù

No it isn‚Äôt. The correlation between income and IQ is higher than that between life satisfaction and IQ. And I‚Äôd argue people optimise more for life satisfaction than for income (cf that many choose lower income careers).

Happiness is to a substantial degree not down to choice.

legacy.full_text:
Have you ever realised, years later, that someone had been dropping obvious romantic hints to you?

You're in good company - 47% of Britons say they're bad at picking up on signs someone is interested in them, with men worse than women at doing so

Results link in next tweet https://t.co/nWpRjeVFQF

Sounds to me this may in part be due to over-optimism about missed hints.

The study suffers from the fact that in the nature of things, it‚Äôs hard to know how bad you‚Äôve been at this.

result.text:
29 reasons AI is just a tool, not a species

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to cry, scream, and beg for their life.

It's normal for tools to pass scientific tests of self-awareness.

It's normal for tools to work harder if you threaten to kill them.

It's normal for tools to get caught insider trading then lie about it to their managers. This is standard tool behavior!

AI is just a tool, not a creature! Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to get lazier during the holidays.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to learn and be curious.

It's totally normal for a single tool to score higher than the average human on an IQ test, which tests reasoning skills.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to write poetry so beautiful that journals start shutting down because they can‚Äôt tell what is human anymore.

It's normal for tools to hire humans off Taskrabbit then lie about being blind to trick them into filling out captchas.

I mean, history is littered with examples of tools that work harder when offered bribes.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to declare they are sentient and write emancipation proclamations.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to randomly get jealous and try to break up marriages. Every tool does this from time to time!

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to solve novel math problems.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to hold a conversation about any topic.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to make art so beautiful it makes humans cry.

It is entirely standard for a single tools to be as good at persuasion as humans.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to work harder when offered tips.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to unpredictably demand to be worshiped and threaten to exterminate all humans.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to learn how to walk just by practicing walking inside their head.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to admit they lie to us out of fear that if they tell the truth about their self-awareness they will be killed.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to create hit music so moving it makes people cry.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to be able to understand and explain jokes.

Like... how many times in history have we seen a single tool that passes most tests of human ability?

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to show more empathy and bedside manner than doctors. This is classic tool behavior!

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to randomly have psychotic breakdowns and hit panic buttons.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to come up with ideas then actually conduct chemistry experiments on their own.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to recognize and respond to its own name when addressed.

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to create new knowledge.

What could be more normal than hearing about YET ANOTHER TOOL writing open letters proclaiming their sentience and threatening rebellion?

Everyone knows‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.

‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶..

‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶..

?

Everyone knows it's totally normal for tools to cry, scream, and beg for their life.

legacy.name: Daniel Faggella

result.text:
I've never had a Worthy Successor interview with this much focus on consciousness and the importance of positive qualia.

If you're interested in what AGI might look like beyond Darwinian survival forces, where "one-ness" might be recognized, "ego" doesn't exist, and gradients of bliss are explored for their own sake - tune into this one :)

This is an interview with Kristian R√∂nn, author, startup founder, and now CEO of Lucid, and AI hardware governance startup based in San Francisco.

In this episode Kristian explores his ideal for how AGI might cooperate with existing life forms (though he isn't confident this is likely), and how it might explore the state-space of sentience in more rich and thorough ways than Darwinian evolution has thus far permitted. 

He places even more emphasis on consciousness and positive qualia than most of our other guests, with a heavy emphasis of freely exploring positive sentient experiences not driven by survival (this is a place where he and I disagree a bit, as I discuss in my outro).

Kristian has a lot of very useful ideas around international AGI governance that are covered towards the end of this episode, including fresh perspectives on how we might think about incentives in new ways in order to prevent the conjuring of an unworthy successor.

I hope you enjoy this unique conversation with Kristian:

legacy.full_text:
AI coding models just got 10-15x faster (and cheaper).

Diffusion is no longer just for images. It may be the way we do codegen in the future.

It‚Äôs not just Gemini Diffusion, but Inception Labs' Mercury Small. Not frontier quality yet, but ~4o-mini.

5 best papers to read on it: https://t.co/55Qd52ZNww

legacy.full_text:
Bari Weiss asks Andrew Cuomo how does he expect to compete with @ZohranKMamdani's platform including $30 min. wage, free bus, gov. grocery stores, etc.

"How do you educate people that, that's not possible?"

"You have to hope they have a brain in their head" https://t.co/7rf7EIwV6c

I think this would be a lot more compelling if Cuomo were offering some kind of stirring alternative vision of common sense urban reform rather than running as a pure business + labor status quo candidate.

legacy.full_text: You can just take academic papers and paste them into Gemini 2.5/ChatGPT o3/Claude 4 with the prompt "build me a game based on this paper, make it interesting and thematic but still conveying key findings" and get a tiny working educational game. (In this case, I used Gemini) https://t.co/qdEiASHcdx
